info.game_comments:
2002 College Championship final game 1.
From the Schottenstein Center at the Ohio State University in Columbus.

(1, 1).clue: This hero went "forth upon the Gitche Gumee... with his fishing-line of cedar" to catch a sturgeon

(2, 1).clue: A pair of magic ruby slippers is at the center of this classic 1939 film

(3, 1).clue: Capt. Robert FitzRoy commanded the Beagle on the 1831-36 expedition with this naturalist

(4, 1).clue: If you were jealous of someone's pack of crayons, you'd be this "with envy"

(5, 1).clue: While an alligator has about 80 of these at any one time, they wear down & are eventually replaced

(6, 1).clue: In comic books, a series of this letter is used to represent a person snoring

(1, 2).clue: He wrote his 1914 poem "Chicago" while working as a newspaper writer in that city

(2, 2).clue: Harry Potter's teachers include Madam Hooch, who teaches flying on one of these

(3, 2).clue: Sacajawea gave birth to a son, Jean-Baptiste Charbonneau, during this duo's 1803-06 expedition

(4, 2).clue: Before tan was added in 1949, this was the only 3-letter color in the box

(5, 2).clue: On this largest Louisiana city's seal, the alligator represents the city's marshes & swamps

(6, 2).clue: In religious writing, this symbol of the Greek letter chi represents Christ

(1, 3).clue: For writing the pamphlet "The Necessity of Atheism", this "Ode to the West Wind" poet was expelled from Oxford

(2, 3).clue: The Mages, an elite group of magic users, rule the empire of Izmer in this 2000 film based on a role-playing game

(3, 3).clue: He was born Fernao de Magalhaes around 1480 in northern Portugal

(4, 3).clue: Color for the belly of your sapsucker or a caution card in soccer

(5, 3).clue: The Alligator River of Australia actually contains these related reptiles, not alligators

(6, 3).clue: This letter paired with "H" at the end of a word sometimes results in an "F" sound

(1, 4).clue: The first line of this poem is "Sing, goddess, the anger of Peleus's son Achilles"

(2, 4).clue: Distinctive actor seen here as 1954's "The Mad Magician"

(3, 4).clue: Famous for his greeting "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?", he discovered Africa's Mountains of the Moon

(4, 4).clue: These 2 common eye colors are the school colors of Tufts University

(5, 4).clue: This "Alligator State" made the alligator its official state reptile in 1987

(6, 4).clue: In German, it usually has the sound that English gives to the letter before it in the alphabet

(1, 5).clue: In 1899 this Irish poet & dramatist co-founded the Irish literary theatre, which later became the Abbey Theatre

(2, 5).clue: In a 1998 film, Nicole Kidman & this "Miss Congeniality" star are sisters with a gift for "Practical Magic"

(3, 5).clue: Between 1903 & 1905 this Norwegian discovered the exact location of the North Magnetic Pole

(4, 5).clue: More recently it's been burnt, outrageous & sunset; back in 1903 it was just this

(5, 5).clue: The alligator snapper isn't an alligator but one of these reptiles

(6, 5).clue: Used chiefly in poetic or religious invocations, it's an interjection expressing strong emotion

(1, 1).clue: (Alex reports on location.)  At the Sweetwaters Game Reserve in east Africa, chimpanzees are cared for at a sanctuary that works closely with this world-famous chimp researcher

(2, 1).clue: Brides often adorn their heads with this delicate fabric; the Alencon type would look lovely on you

(3, 1).clue: It's the only element on the chart with exactly the same name as a planet in our solar system

(4, 1).clue: He was People Magazine's "Top Gun" for 1990

(5, 1).clue: The Grand Ole Opry Museum & the Music Valley Wax Museum are attractions in this city

(1, 2).clue: There are 2 kinds of African rhino, each with a colorful name; this smaller one has a prehensile upper lip

(2, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports) Despite the ending of the play, many a bride has worn a cap named for this Capulet

(3, 2).clue: The symbols of elements 17, 18 & 19 combine to form the last name of this "Bandstand" & "Other Half" host

(4, 2).clue: "O Brother", this former star of "ER" was the Sexiest Man Alive in 1997

(5, 2).clue: Camel Butte & the Mittens are 2 of the mineral sandstone structures that give this AZ./Utah "valley" its name

(6, 2).clue: This physician specializes in the care of children, from infancy to adolescence

(1, 3).clue: An unmarked coat below the knee is a trait of the giraffe subspecies named this, like an international banking family

(2, 3).clue: In contrast to chapel length, a veil of this church length sounds perfect for a wedding at St. Paul's

(3, 3).clue: 1 of the only 2 letters not found in the abbreviations of elements with atomic numbers up to 100

(4, 3).clue: Maybe because it was the luck of the Irish that in 2001 this James Bond star was the Sexiest Man Alive

(5, 3).clue: A midnight trip to this Freeport, Maine retailer founded in 1912 is a tradition for college students in New England

(6, 3).clue: General term for an animal without a backbone

(1, 4).clue: Some say these antelopes were built from spare parts, yet they're among Africa's most numerous mammals

(2, 4).clue: The height of Spanish style, it's often worn over a comb & has a name derived from manta, Spanish for "cape"

(3, 4).clue: The seventh period begins with francium followed by this element discovered in France in 1898

(4, 4).clue: This star of "The Mothman Prophecies" took the title in 1999

(5, 4).clue: Located in northwest Montana, this national park has 1,500 square miles of ice-carved terrain

(6, 4).clue: It can mean one's physical health or a 1787 document

(1, 5).clue: (Alex reports from Kenya.)  They are not Kenya's largest tribe, but these pastorialists in their bright red traditional shukas are certainly the country's most recognizable

(2, 5).clue: A ballerina might wear a veil made of this tutu fabric that also starts with the letters "TU"

(3, 5).clue: After helium it's the NeXT noble gas on the table

(4, 5).clue: This African-American actor must have been in all his "Glory" when he was chosen in 1996

(5, 5).clue: "Footsteps to Freedom" is an exhibit at this Alabama city's National Voting Rights Museum

(6, 5).clue: It's the 12-letter adjective for Edison's practical electric bulb, successfully tested at Menlo Park Oct. 21, 1879

(0, 0).clue: One of the original titles of this 1925 novel was "Among Ash Heaps and Millionaires"
